content.description: Start in the hueco on the left wall of the cave, pull your feet on, then bump out to the lip. 1st crux is moving from this position into a spot where you can continue up and right along the rim. Same top-out as “Ataraxia”.
content.location: Two hand start in hueco on the caves left wall.

content.description: Good foot work to move you out in order to walk your hands up the rail is the only trick!
content.location: Lowest ribbon of rock is not on route (still mostly covered in dirt). Start in a compression with the right hand on the base of the right facing rail - left hand on the only optional hold feet left and deep to the rail. Feet out right on middle ribbon of rock (see pic). Move out to the rail, then climb up, pulling the lip for a top!

content.description: Sit start, and climb the rightmost ramp of the cave. No defining crux. Broken into 3 main portions: bumping to a crimp so you can drop your body down, climbing your hands up the sloppy ramp toward the finish, and keeping your feet on the wall to before pulling the lip. Fun movement with fun holds the whole way.
content.location: Sit start in the rightmost portion of the cave. Both hands in the big dish formation, right heel can be up, on the lip, left toe on a ledge under the overhang (pic uploaded that shoes start position). Drop into the edge, bump hand out to a crispy edge gouged out of the rich, and begin the traverse. The top two ribbons of rock are on, but not the lowest ribbon which is mainly in the dirt. Pull the lip for the finish when you reach the right facing rail (same finish site as “Slippery When Wet”)

content.description: Pretty well-sustained on slopers. Choreographing the correct hand/heel placement may take a few attempts, but it’s a fairly straightforward climb up to the final holds.
content.location: Left-most climb. Start by standing on a rectangular block with a large root growing over the top of it. This root is on for a toe hook, and there is a bulbous portion of this root a few feet up from the block for your hands to start on. From here, lower down into the lip. Pocketed feet extend deeper into the cave, while slopers pave the way up to the peak of the climb. A hidden rail will assist you in the final lip-pull just before getting to the drainage area at the center of the cave’s lip.

content.description: Crux: the last few moves - finding how to move over into the drainage section to pull the lip. Movement is great - forcing good utilization of heals and toes. Holds can be dirty and hard to see, so brush and mark to optimize the send.
content.location: Start in a huge undercling (just down and right from a right-facing rail toward the right end of the cave). Use lower foot block and rail to move onto the lip of the cave. Work left to the center (drainage area) of the cave and pull the lip.

content.description: Sandstone cave that has been uncovered from runoff to the lake. Lip of the cave is about 40 feet long end-to-end, and about 7 feet tall at its center. Area receives filtered sun through surrounding trees throughout the day. Holds remain wet and brittle for a day or so after it has rained. Despite it being a “pit” that needs frequent cleaning of holds - quality climbing can be found here. The Petrichor Pit is the only outdoor feature we could find within 1.5 hours of Kirksville. Treat it with love so future ATSU/Truman students & locals can use it. You’ll want a couple crash pads and ideally a spotter.
